author: Kevin Scarbinsky | kscarbinsky@al.com
title: AL.com All-Access: Open 1, Auburn 0
text:
It's an old joke, the one about the football team so bad it loses to Open, that Saturday on the schedule when there is no game. 
Right now at Auburn, it's no joke. 
The Tigers don't have a game scheduled Saturday, their only open date of the season, but there's no other way to look at the events of the last six days. 
They've lost the open week. 
It started last Saturday night after an OK win against overmatched San Jose State when talented but troubled Duke Williams reportedly lost it at an Auburn bar, punching four different people. 
It was reported Thursday that a teammate, backup center Xavier Dampeer, was one of those people and that Dampeer has an injured jaw as a result. 
Gus Malzahn announced Monday that he'd dismissed Williams, the biggest name on the roster, from the team. It was at least the third strike for a player who simply couldn't or wouldn't get with the program. 
Malzahn said Wednesday that Williams would no longer continue taking classes at Auburn. 
From there, Malzahn announced the coaches were opening up a competition at every single position, including quarterback, and there's a feeling that Jeremy Johnson could return as the starter against Kentucky. 
RELATED: Sure seems like Jeremy Johnson's getting another shot 
Competition is good. Open competition across the board five games into the season usually isn't. 
Defensive coordinator Will Muschamp expressed his exasperation with his run defense, suggesting it's so bad he wouldn't even bother throwing the ball if he were an opposing offense. 
"Hell, ain't nobody got to throw it," Muschamp said. "I wouldn't." 
That's an early contender for Auburn quote of the year. 
Auburn players were asked if this season could be headed the way of 2012, when the record bottomed out at 3-9 overall and 0-8 in the SEC and Gene Chizik got fired. Naturally, they said no, but the evidence continues to mount. 
At least one thing seems certain as Auburn approaches the halfway point of a season that hasn't gone as planned. Unless this team made significant improvement behind the scenes at practice - which won't be evident until Thursday night at Kentucky - this was a lost week on the Plains. 
That's my take. What's yours? Bring it to AL.com All-Access, our daily chat, confessional and trollapalooza, from 10-11 a.m.
